TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a national of ORG ( hereinafter “ the FRY ” ) born in DATE . He is currently detained in ORG in GPE , GPE . He is represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE ( GPE ) .
The facts of the case , as apparent from public information and the documents submitted by the applicant , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant was indicted , together with others , by the Prosecutor of ORG for the Former GPE ( hereinafter “ the ORG ” ) . On DATE a judge of ORG of the ORG , finding that there was a prima facie case against the indictees , confirmed the indictment and issued a warrant for their arrest . The applicant was then the President of the FRY .
In DATE the applicant was voted out of office . On DATE he relinquished the position of President of the FRY . He was subsequently arrested on charges brought under FRY domestic law .
On DATE the applicant was transferred to GPE , despite an order of ORG of the FRY suspending his surrender to the ORG pending consideration of its legality .

On DATE the applicant made an initial appearance before ORG , during which he was formally charged and invited to plead guilty or not guilty . The applicant refused to enter a plea but attempted to argue that the ORG was an unlawful institution . The presiding judge refused to hear his arguments . Noting the applicant ’s refusal to plead , ORG ex officio entered a plea of not guilty on his behalf . It also ordered his detention on remand .
On DATE the applicant lodged a preliminary motion arguing , in so far as is relevant here , that the ORG was illegal .

At a status conference on DATE , the applicant attempted to make an oral statement to the effect that the ORG lacked a legitimate basis . He was prevented from so doing by the presiding judge , who invited him to make it in writing in the form of a preliminary motion . The applicant did so .

On DATE , the applicant having refused to be represented before a tribunal which he considered illegal , ORG appointed CARDINAL practising lawyers as amici curiae to defend the applicant ’s interests . On DATE the amici curiae submitted a brief supporting the applicant ’s preliminary motions of CARDINAL and DATE .

On DATE , at a second status conference , ORG gave an oral decision rejecting the applicant ’s preliminary motions . The amici curiae made oral submissions concerning the proposed conduct of the trial . The applicant was allowed to speak uninterrupted . He alleged that ORG was biased , since she had failed to bring prosecutions in connection with the military intervention by ORG member GPE on the territory of the ORG which took place in DATE . He also complained about the conditions in which he was detained , and in particular about the lack of privacy .
ORG decision rejecting the applicant ’s preliminary motions was published in writing , with reasons , on DATE .

The indictment of CARDINAL DATE has been amended on CARDINAL occasions , and CARDINAL further indictments have been brought . The applicant has consistently refused to plead , and pleas of not guilty have been entered on his behalf .

On DATE a hearing was held before ORG of the ORG , the purpose of which was to decide whether the various indictments should be heard in separate sets of proceedings . The applicant submitted a request for his release and promised to appear for any hearings .
On DATE ORG of the ORG decided that the CARDINAL indictments should be heard in a single set of proceedings .
The applicant ’s trial opened on DATE .
It was reported on DATE that the applicant had repeated his request for release to ORG , and on DATE that it had been refused .

The applicant brought summary civil proceedings ( kort geding ) against GPE before the President of ORG ( arrondissementsrechtbank ) of GPE . He sought an order directed against the ORG for his unconditional release ; in the alternative , for him to be returned to the ORG ; in the further alternative , for the ORG to make representations to “ the so - called ORG ” ( i.e. the ORG ) and other competent international bodies and institutions for his release ; in the still further alternative , for the ORG to make representations to “ the alleged ORG ” ( again , i.e. the ORG ) and other competent international bodies and institutions for his return to the FRY . He argued , essentially , that his transfer to the ORG was illegal as a matter of the domestic law of the FRY ; that the ORG itself lacked a basis in international law , having been set up by a resolution of ORG of ORG ( to wit , resolution no . CARDINAL of DATE ) and not by a multilateral treaty ; that the ORG was the handmaiden of ORG and therefore not an independent and impartial tribunal in the sense of LAW ; that the actions of ORG and the ORG were discriminatory ; and that he was entitled to immunity as a former head of state . In view of these considerations GPE was acting unlawfully by allowing him to be detained and remain in detention on its territory ,
A public hearing was held on DATE .

The President of ORG gave judgment on DATE . He found that the ORG did in fact have sufficient legal basis ; that it offered sufficient procedural guarantees , as found by ORG in its GPE v. GPE decision ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , DATE ) ; and that , GPE having lawfully transferred its jurisdiction over the ORG ’s indictees to the ORG , the courts of the GPE were not competent to consider the applicant ’s request for release .
The applicant lodged an appeal against this judgment , but withdrew it again as of DATE .

Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ( Wetboek van Burgerlijke Rechtsvordering ) provides that all cases where a speedy and provisionally enforceable decision is required in the interests of the parties shall be heard in summary proceedings by the President of ORG , who shall set a hearing date on DATE .
Article CARDINAL provides for an appeal against the President ’s judgment to ORG ( gerechtshof ) , and for a further appeal – on points of law –to ORG ( PERSON ) .
Article ORG provides that a provisionally enforceable decision taken in summary proceedings shall not prejudge the merits of the case .
